title: Incentivizing Truthful Collaboration in Heterogeneous Federated Learning

sections.text:
## Abstract

Federated learning (FL) is a distributed collaborative learning method, where multiple clients learn together by sharing gradient updates instead of raw data. However, it is well-known that FL is vulnerable to manipulated updates from clients. In this work we study the impact of data heterogeneity on clients' incentives to manipulate their updates. First, we present heterogeneous collaborative learning scenarios where a client can modify their updates to be better off, and show that these manipulations can lead to diminishing model performance. To prevent such modifications, we formulate a game in which clients may misreport their gradient updates in order to "steer" the server model to their advantage. We develop a payment rule that provably disincentivizes sending modified updates under the FedSGD protocol. We derive explicit bounds on the clients' payments and the convergence rate of the global model, which allows us to study the trade-off between heterogeneity, payments and convergence. Finally, we provide an experimental evaluation of the effectiveness of our payment rule in the FedSGD, median-based aggregation FedSGD and FedAvg protocols on three tasks in computer vision and natural language processing. In all cases we find that our scheme successfully disincentivizes modifications.

## 1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL) (McMahan et al., 2017) enables the efficient training of machine learning models on large datasets, distributed among multiple stakeholders, via gradient updates shared with a central server. FL has the potential to provide state-of-the-art models in multiple domains where high-quality training data is scarce and distributed (Kairouz et al., 2021). For example, FL can be a major advancement in fields like healthcare (Rieke et al., 2020), agriculture (Durrant et al., 2022), transportation (Tan et al., 2020) and finance (Long et al., 2020; Oualid et al., 2023).

Unfortunately, the distributed nature of standard FL protocols makes them susceptible to clients misreporting their gradient updates. Indeed, it is known that the presence of market competition (Dorner et al., 2023), privacy concerns (Tsoy et al., 2024) and high data gathering costs (Karimireddy et al., 2022) may incentivize clients to communicate updates that are harmful for the global model. Furthermore, prior work has shown that a small fraction of malicious participants can damage the learned model with seemingly benign updates (Blanchard et al., 2017; Alistarh et al., 2018). These issues bring the practical merit of federated learning in the presence of misaligned incentives into question.

In the current work, we show that incentives for update manipulation may appear even between clients who are solely interested in their own accuracy, as long as they have different data distributions. Since data heterogeneity is ubiquitous in common federated learning scenarios (McMahan et al., 2017; Kairouz et al., 2021), this implies that clients could be incentivized to manipulate their updates in realistic scenarios and even without the presence of explicitly conflicting goals, such as those arising from competition and privacy.

# 1.1 Main contributions 

We introduce a game-theoretic framework that models rational client behavior in the context of heterogeneous FL and provide a payment mechanism that successfully disincentives possibly harmful gradient modifications, which ensures training convergence. Our main theoretical contributions are as follows:

- We propose a game-theoretic framework for studying the impact of heterogeneous data on the incentive of clients to modify their gradient updates before sending them to the server. This model allows for several natural types of update manipulations, as well as various reward functions for the clients. We show that this enables modeling various real-world client incentives.
- We design a budget-balanced payment mechanism that when used in conjunction with the FedSGD protocol achieves both (1) $\varepsilon$-approximate incentive compatibility-truthful reporting results in utility that is $\varepsilon$-close to optimal for a client $i$ given that everyone else is sending truthful updates, and (2) $\varepsilon$-approximately truthful reporting - the best response of client $i$ when everyone else is sending truthful updates is $\varepsilon$-close to the truthfulness.
- We prove the convergence of FedSGD with standard rates for smooth, strongly-convex objectives, when executed for clients who report $\varepsilon$-approximately truthfully under our payment scheme. In the same context, we also provide an upper bound on the total payment of each client.
Beyond theory, we empirically investigate the effectiveness of our payment mechanism on three (non-convex) tasks: image classification on the FeMNIST dataset, sentiment analysis on the Twitter dataset, and nextcharacter prediction on the Shakespeare dataset (Caldas et al., 2018). We observe that our payment mechanism successfully eliminates the incentive for gradient manipulation in all three tasks. Finally, we provide empirical evidence that our method generalizes to other FL protocols, such as median-based FedSGD, which aims to aggregate gradients robustly, and FedAvg, the classical FL protocol of McMahan et al. (2017).

### 1.2 Related work

Heterogeneity in Federated Learning. The impact of data heterogeneity on the quality of the learned model is of central interest in the FL literature. Some works study how to train a central model and also provide personalization, in order to maximize the accuracy for each client (McMahan et al., 2017; Mansour et al., 2020; Marfoq et al., 2022; Mishchenko et al., 2023). Others focus on the impact of heterogeneity on model convergence and on designing algorithms that provide more accurate centralized models in a heterogeneous environment (Karimireddy et al., 2020; Khaled et al., 2020; Koloskova et al., 2020; Woodworth et al., 2020; Patel et al., 2024).

These works tackle issues of data heterogeneity from the server's perspective, while we take a mechanismdesign point of view and focus on the clients' behavior. Prior work (Chayti et al., 2021) has also explored how to adapt to heterogeneity from a client's perspective, by optimally weighting local and server updates. Instead, in the current paper, we study how clients might manipulate their messages to the server, thus damaging the global training process, and our aim is to mitigate this potential manipulation. Another client behavior driven by the heterogeneity of client data is studied by Donahue and Kleinberg (2021a,b), who, however, model FL as a coalitional game, where players need to decide how to cluster in groups to improve their performance. In contrast, we study non-cooperative games and clients' incentives to manipulate their updates.

Robustness in Federated Learning. Prior work has explored the robustness of FL to noise and bias towards subgroups, e.g. Abay et al. (2020); Fang and Ye (2022). Several works also consider Byzantinerobust learning (Blanchard et al., 2017; Yin et al., 2018; Alistarh et al., 2018). We refer to Shejwalkar et al. (2022) for a recent survey. Moreover, Pillutla et al. (2022) propose a robust aggregation procedure that is similar to the way we construct our penalty scheme.

Our work takes a different approach towards securing FL from potentially harmful updates: we model the clients as rational agents in a game and seek to ensure that honest reporting is close to their utility optimal. This way the global model can benefit from diverse data, while disinsentivizing gradient manipulation.

Incentives in Collaborative Learning. A major research direction is that of studying whether clients have an incentive to join the FL protocol, relative to participation costs (e.g. compute resources and data

collection costs). We refer to Tu et al. (2021); Zhan et al. (2021) for recent surveys. Additionally, Tsoy et al. (2024) explore the impact of privacy concerns on FL participation incentives. Among works that consider incentives for manipulating updates, Karimireddy et al. (2022) focus on free-riding, Han et al. (2023) study defection, Blum et al. (2021) look at agents who wish to keep their data collection low, while Huang et al. (2023) try to incentivize diverse data contributions. Moreover, Dorner et al. (2023) consider manipulating updates due to incentives stemming from competition, focusing on homogeneous SGD.

In contrast to these works, we consider clients who are solely interested in their own accuracy and utility, but, as we show, may still have conflicting incentives due to data heterogeneity.

# 2 Preliminaries 

In this section we introduce our heterogeneous FL setup.

### 2.1 FL setup and protocol

Learning setup. We consider a standard FL setting with $N$ clients who seek to obtain an accurate model by exchanging messages (gradient updates) with a central server, which orchestrates the protocol. All clients work with a shared loss function $f(\theta ; z)$ that is differentiable, convex and smooth in $\theta \in \mathcal{Z}$ for every $z$. Each client $i$ has her own distribution $D_{i}$ over the data $z \in \mathcal{Z},{ }^{1}$ and is interested in minimizing the expected loss with respect to their own distribution, i.e. the loss function of client $i$ is $F_{i}(\theta)=\mathbb{E}_{z \sim D_{i}}[f(\theta ; z)]$. We assume that

$$
\nabla F_{i}(\theta)=\mathbb{E}_{z \sim D_{i}}[f(\theta ; z)]
$$

and that there exists a scalar $\sigma \geq 0$, such that

$$
\mathbb{E}_{z \sim D_{i}}\left[\left\|f(\theta ; z)-\nabla F_{i}(\theta)\right\|^{2}\right] \leq \sigma^{2}
$$

In other words, we assume that for each client their stochastic gradient is an unbiased estimator for their full gradient and has bounded variance. Unless otherwise stated, all norms are $\ell_{2}$ norms. We further require that $F_{i}$ is $m$-strongly-convex and $H$-smooth for each client $i$.

Definition 2.1 (Strong convexity). A differentiable function $F: \mathcal{X} \subseteq \mathbb{R}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ is $m$-strongly-convex if for all $x, y \in \mathcal{X}$ :

$$
F(x) \geq F(y)+\langle\nabla F(y), x-y\rangle+\frac{m}{2}\|x-y\|^{2}
$$

Definition 2.2 (Smoothness). A differentiable function $F: \mathcal{X} \subseteq \mathbb{R}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ is $H$-smooth if for all $x, y \in \mathcal{X}$ :

$$
\|\nabla F(x)-\nabla F(y)\| \leq H\|x-y\|
$$

Finally, the server's objective is to minimize the average expected loss of all clients, i.e.

$$
F(\theta)=\frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^{N} F_{i}(\theta)
$$

FL protocol. We consider the standard FedSGD protocol, where the server asks the clients to send stochastic gradients at the current model, with respect to their own data distribution. At each time step $t$ client $i$ computes a stochastic gradient $g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right):=\nabla f\left(\theta_{t} ; z\right)$ by sampling from their distribution $z \sim D_{i}$ independently of everything else. We also let $e_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)=g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)-\nabla F_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)$ be the gradient noise. The server then updates the central model by averaging the updates and taking an SGD step, i.e. $\theta_{t+1}=\theta_{t}-\gamma_{t} \frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^{N} g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)$, where $\gamma_{t}$ is the learning rate at step $t$.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{1}$ We do not assume any parametric form of the distributions.

# 2.2 Heterogeneity assumptions 

To describe the relation between the data distributions, we invoke an assumption reminiscent to the standard bounded first-order heterogeneity assumption from the FL literature on the convergence rates of local and mini-batch SGD (Karimireddy et al., 2020; Khaled et al., 2020; Koloskova et al., 2020; Woodworth et al., 2020; Patel et al., 2024). Assumption 2.3 restricts the size of the gradient $\nabla F_{i}$ of client $i$ 's objective $F_{i}$ relative to the gradient $\nabla F$ of the aggregate objective $F$. While standard first-order assumptions previously used in Karimireddy et al. (2020); Khaled et al. (2020); Koloskova et al. (2020); Woodworth et al. (2020); Patel et al. (2024) (for formal statements see Assumption B. 1 and B. 2 in Appendix B) usually require the gradients of the objectives to be close in some vector norm, we only require them to be close in magnitude.

Assumption 2.3 (Bounded Gradient Difference). For every client $i$ and every $\theta \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$, we have

$$
\left|\left\|\nabla F_{i}(\theta)\right\|^{2}-\|\nabla F(\theta)\|^{2}\right| \leq \zeta^{2}
$$

As a consequence $\left|\left\|\nabla F_{i}(\theta)\right\|^{2}-\left\|\nabla F_{j}(\theta)\right\|^{2}\right| \leq 2 \zeta^{2}$.
Next, Assumption 2.4 controls the difference between the variance of stochastic gradients. This allows us to cover scenarios, where the objectives are sufficiently similar, but the variance of some client $i$ (relative to others) might induce an incentive to misreport. We employ it in our bound on individual payments in Proposition 5.2.

Assumption 2.4 (Bounded Variance Difference). For any pair of clients $i, j \in[N]$ and any $\theta \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$, we have

$$
\left|\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|e_{i}(\theta)\right\|^{2}\right]-\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|e_{j}(\theta)\right\|^{2}\right]\right| \leq \rho^{2}
$$

where $\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|e_{i}(\theta)\right\|^{2}\right]$ is the variance of the $\ell_{2}$ norm of the error vector $e_{i}(\theta)=g_{i}(\theta)-\nabla F_{i}(\theta)$.
We note that the parameters $\zeta$ and $\rho$ have a natural interpretation as the amount of heterogeneity among the FL clients.

## 3 Motivating examples

We now present a couple of motivating examples about how a strategic client can take advantage within the protocol by misreporting, due to heterogeneity in the clients' data. First, we present a conceptually easier example with single-round mean estimation. This example provides intuition about why upscaling a gradient can help steer the aggregate gradient closer to the true gradient of some client $i$, and in the process move the model to a position that is more favorable for client $i$. Note that mean estimation can be interpreted as a single step of the learning process. Then we give a simplified example with gradient descent and illustrate a scenario where one client's misreporting can make other clients worse off.

### 3.1 Example with Mean Estimation

Suppose $N$ clients seek to estimate their respective means $\mu_{1}, \ldots, \mu_{N} \in \mathbb{R}$, where without loss of generality $\mu_{1}>\mu_{2}>\ldots>\mu_{N}$. First, each client gets a sample $x_{i} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(\mu_{i}, \sigma^{2}\right)$, and sends a message $m_{i}$ (supposedly their sample $x_{i}$ ) to the server. Then the server computes an aggregate $\bar{\mu}=\frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^{N} m_{i}$ and broadcasts it to all clients. Each client $i$ would like to receive an estimate of their local mean with minimal mean squared error $\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\bar{\mu}-\mu_{i}\right)^{2}\right]$.

Proposition 3.1. Let $\mu=\frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^{N} \mu_{i}$ and assume that $\mu_{1}\left(\mu_{1}-\mu\right)>\sigma^{2} / N$ and that everyone but the first client truthfully reports their sample. If client 1 truthfully reports their sample $x_{1}$, then $\mathbb{E}[\bar{\mu}]=\mu$ and $\operatorname{Var}(\bar{\mu})=\sigma^{2} / N$, and so

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\bar{\mu}-\mu_{1}\right)^{2}\right]=\left(\mu-\mu_{1}\right)^{2}+\frac{\sigma^{2}}{N}
$$

![img-0.jpeg](img-0.jpeg)

Figure 1: The plot follows Proposition 3.2. Clients are represented by colors, and their respective loss functions (variants of quadratic loss) are shown next to their color in the legend. The black curve is the average loss function over all clients, and the legend shows the optimum. The red client scales their gradients by a constant, in this case $3 \times$; the dotted red line is their new loss function, and the dotted black line is the new average loss. The new global optimum is better for the red client, while it's worse for the green client.

However, there exists a constant $c>1$, such that if client 1 sends $c x_{1}$, they reduce their MSE to

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\tilde{\mu}-\mu_{1}\right)^{2}\right]=\left(\mu-\mu_{1}\right)^{2}+\frac{\sigma^{2}}{N}-\frac{\left(\sigma^{2} / N-\mu_{1}\left(\mu_{1}-\mu\right)\right)^{2}}{\mu_{1}^{2}+\sigma^{2}}
$$

The proof of Proposition 3.1 alongside additional results for this example setup can be found in Appendix D. The assumption $\mu_{1}\left(\mu_{1}-\mu\right)>\sigma^{2} / N$ holds whenever the heterogeneity of the data distributions $\left(\mu-\mu_{1}\right)$ is large with respect to the variance $\sigma^{2} / N$ of the aggregated message.

The conclusion of Proposition 3.1 is that there is some client that is incentivized to magnify their sample in order to reduce their final error. In words, client 1 , whose target mean $\mu_{1}$ is far from the global $\mu$, can attempt to bias the aggregated mean estimate in their favor by altering their update to be more extreme.
Remark. In Appendix D. 3 we investigate the Nash equilibrium of the mean estimation game, where all clients can scale their gradient updates by a personal constant $c_{i}$. Contrast this with Proposition 3.1, which considers the incentive-compatible regime-we fix all but client $i$ to report truthful gradients and then derive the optimal strategy for $i$. We find that, for a large number of clients and at the equilibrium, the clients have an incentive to deviate and, on average, increase their weight, thus making their contribution a biased estimate of their true mean. This results in a higher error for all participants, because the final estimate is now biased and has higher variance.

# 3.2 Example with Stochastic Gradient Descent 

In order to show the effects of gradient modification we opt to work with the simpler gradient descent, so both the objective function and the gradients are deterministic, without stochasticity from data sampling or noise. Proposition 3.2 considers a set of four clients each having a square loss, where one of them has incentive to amplify their gradient update.

Example 3.2. Consider four clients with objective functions: $F_{1}(x)=x^{2}, F_{2}(x)=(x-1)^{2}+1, F_{3}(x)=$ $3(x-2)^{2}+2, F_{4}(x)=(x-0.5)^{2}+3$. Their average objective is $F(x)=1.5 x^{2}-3.75 x+4.8125$ and achieves minimal value at $x^{*}=\frac{5}{3}$. Suppose client 1 sends a gradient $g(x)=6 x$ as if his objective is $F_{1}^{\prime}(x)=3 x^{2}$. The new average objective is $F^{\prime}(x)=2 x^{2}-3.75 x+4.8125$ with minimal value at $x^{* *}=\frac{15}{16}$. Then client 1 is better off, i.e. $F_{1}\left(x^{* *}\right)<F_{1}\left(x^{*}\right)$, while client 3 is worse off, i.e. $F_{3}\left(x^{* *}\right)>F_{3}\left(x^{*}\right)$.

See Figure 1 for visualization of Proposition 3.2. The proposition illustrates how gradient amplification can be beneficial for some client, while making other clients worse off. The final model is better performing for client 1 (red on Figure 1), while client 1's modification leads to client 3 (green on Figure 1) being worse off compared to when all clients were truthful.

# 4 Game-theoretic framework 

Motivated by the examples in Section 3 we introduce a game setup which captures these strategic interactions.
Action Space. We consider a game in which the clients seek to improve their own loss function by manipulating the messages they send to the server. Specifically, at time $t$ each client sends message $m_{t}^{i}=$ $a_{t}^{i} g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)+b_{t}^{i} \xi_{t}^{i}$, for some constants $\left|a_{t}^{i}\right| \geq 1, b_{t}^{i} \geq 0$ chosen by the client. Here $\xi_{t}^{i}$ is a random vector that is independent of everything else and satisfies $\mathbb{E}\left[\xi_{t}^{i}\right]=0$ and $\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\xi_{t}^{i}\right\|^{2}\right]=1$. We also cover generalizations of the action space in Subsection 5.3. The rest of the process remains unchanged, with the server computing $\bar{m}_{t}=\frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^{N} m_{t}^{i}$ and $\theta_{t+1}=\theta_{t}-\gamma_{t} \bar{m}_{t}$, and communicating $\theta_{t+1}$ to all clients at each round.

The scaling factor $a_{t}^{i}$ gives a client $i$ the ability to magnify their gradient update, as in the examples in Section 3, so that the aggregation method computes a mean gradient that could produce a final model that is more beneficial for client $i$. The additional noise term $b_{t}^{i} \xi_{t}^{i}$ is a natural way to also account for (1) clients wanting to obscure portions of their data, while amplifying the gradient effect of other portions, and/or (2) the clients adding differential-privacy noise to their updates for privacy-preserving reasons.

Utility and Reward Functions. As is standard in game theory, we assume that the clients are rational, i.e. they seek to select actions $\left(a_{t}^{i}, b_{t}^{i}\right)$ that increase their utility. We let the utility $U_{i}$ of client $i$ to be

$$
U_{i}=R_{i}(\theta)-p_{i}
$$

where $R_{i}$ is the reward client $i$ gets from the end model $\theta$, and $p_{i}$ is the total payment client $i$ pays. Under a standard FL setting, $p_{i}=0$ and clients observe only a reward that is a function of the final model. We introduce the option of payments to mitigate the incentive for gradient modification. In our theoretical analysis (see Section 5) we require that $R_{i}(\theta)$ is $L$-Lipschitz in $\theta$.
Definition 4.1 (Lipschitzness). A function $R: \mathcal{X} \subseteq \mathbb{R}^{n} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{m}$ is $L$-Lipschitz if for all $x, y \in \mathcal{X}$ :

$$
\|R(x)-R(y)\| \leq L\|x-y\|
$$

Desiderata. We seek to design a payment mechanism, or payment rule, such that the clients are incentivized to send meaningful updates, in order for the final model to achieve small loss on the global objective $F(\theta)$. In particular, we would like our payment mechanism to satisfy two properties: (1) client $i$ does not lose much if they send truthful updates, i.e. whenever all clients $j \neq i$ are reporting truthfully, then truthful reporting is $\varepsilon$-close to the optimal utility for client $i$ (see Definition 4.2), and (2) client $i$ 's best strategy is not too different from their true update, i.e. the best response strategy of client $i$ when everyone else is reporting truthfully is $\varepsilon$-close to truthful reporting (see Definition 4.3). Below we formally define these two desirable properties for a federated learning protocol. ${ }^{2}$
Definition 4.2 ( $\varepsilon$-Bayesian Incentive Compatibility). A federated learning protocol $M$ is $\varepsilon$-Bayesian Incentive Compatible (BIC) if:

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[U_{i}^{M}\left(\left\{\mathbf{1}_{j}\right\}_{j=1}^{N}\right)\right] \geq \mathbb{E}\left[U_{i}^{M}\left(\mathbf{s}_{i},\left\{\mathbf{1}_{j}\right\}_{j \neq i}\right)\right]-\varepsilon
$$

where $\mathbf{1}_{i}=(1, \ldots, 1) \in \mathbb{R}^{T}$ denotes fully truthful participation by client $i, \mathbf{s}_{i}=\left\{s_{i}^{i}\right\}_{t=1}^{T}$ is some arbitrary strategy of client $i$, where $s_{i}^{i}$ is the strategy used by client $i$ at step $t$, and $U_{i}^{M}(\mathbf{v})$ is the utility of client $i$ from $M$ when clients are using the strategy profile $\mathbf{v}$. Note that expectation is taken over the randomness in the clients' distributions, and any randomness (possibly none) in the protocol.

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{2}$ Appendix C compares the usual definition of Bayesian Incentive Compatibility with the one in this section. Usually the definition is phrased in terms of player types, which determine the payoff matrix/valuation function. Here we consider an equivalent formulation in terms of step-wise strategies and the final utility they produce.

In other words, a protocol is $\varepsilon$-Bayesian Incentive Compatibility if there exists a $\varepsilon$-Bayesian Nash Equilibrium of the game, where all participants are reporting truthfully their gradient updates. Therefore, for each client reporting truthfully is $\varepsilon$-close to best responding to all other clients reporting truthfully. ${ }^{3}$

Definition 4.3 ( $\varepsilon$-Approximately truthful reporting). A strategy $\left(a_{t}^{i}, b_{t}^{i}\right)$ of client $i$ is approximately truthful if it satisfies $\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|a_{t}^{i} g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)-g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\right] \leq \varepsilon^{2}$ and $b_{t}^{i} \leq \varepsilon .{ }^{4}$ Moreover, in our analysis we require that the best response of client $i$ to truthful participation by clients $j \neq i$ is approximately truthful.

# 4.1 A note on reward functions 

Notice that our only constraint on the reward function $R_{i}(\theta)$ is for it to be $L$-Lipschitz. This allows our framework to cover a wide range of reward scenarios of practical interest. Below, we present several examples, starting with our primary motivation of modeling selfishness of heterogeneous clients.

Selfishness due to heterogeneity. Our primary motivation is to model clients who are selfish due to heterogeneity - they would like the final model to be as good as possible on their data distribution and the heterogeneity of client distributions creates an incentive to deviate from truthful participation. Mathematically, we can write this as $R_{i}(\theta) \sim-F_{i}(\theta)$, where we use $\sim$ to denote that $R_{i}(\theta)$ grows with $-F_{i}(\theta)$, i.e. as $F_{i}(\theta)$ decreases, $R_{i}(\theta)$ increases. For example, we could capture the phenomenon of diminishing returns by modeling the reward for client $i$ with the logistic function $R_{i}(\theta)=\frac{1}{1+e^{-L / F_{i}(\theta)}}$ (Girdzijauskas and Štreimikiené, 2007).

Inter-client dynamics. We can model cooperative behavior if the reward $R_{i}(\theta) \sim \frac{-i}{\|S_{i}\|} \sum_{j \in S_{i}} F_{j}(\theta)$ depends on the average loss of the clients in the group $S_{i}$ that client $i$ belongs to (akin to Donahue and Kleinberg (2021a,b)). Moreover, we can also model antagonistic behavior similar to Dorner et al. (2023) by setting the reward $R_{i}(\theta) \sim-\alpha F_{i}(\theta)+\frac{\beta}{N-1} \sum_{j \neq i} F_{j}(\theta)$ to depend on some weighted sum of the model performance for client $i$ and the negative of the model performance for the other clients (so client $i$ want to do well, while others shouldn't).

Additional fixed utilities. Because the Lipschitz property is oblivious to translations (in $\mathbb{R}^{d}$ ), the reward function can accommodate situations where clients have fixed upfront utility that is independent of the final model $\theta$ and the history of the protocol: (1) upfront costs, (2) incentives to participate, (3) incentives to collect and transmit quality data, (4) subsidies. In particular, because of this our setup complements models that seek to handle free-riding (Karimireddy et al., 2022; Han et al., 2023) and quality data collection (Blum et al., 2021).

## 5 Theoretical results

In this section, we study a payment scheme which we prove is both $\varepsilon$-BIC and incentivizes approximately truthful reporting. We also provide explicit bounds on the penalties a client may pay and on the achieved rates of convergence of the global model, whenever the clients are approximately truthful. Finally, we discuss trade-offs between truthfulness, payment size and convergence.

At each step $t$ the server charges client $i$ the payment:

$$
p_{t}^{i}\left(\vec{m}_{t}\right)=C_{t}\left[\left\|m_{t}^{i}\right\|^{2}-\frac{1}{N-1} \sum_{j \neq i}\left\|m_{t}^{j}\right\|^{2}\right]
$$

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{3}$ Moreover, the Relevation Principle from Mechanism Design states that any mechanism, where players are not necessarily being truthful, can be implemented by an incentive compatible mechanism with the same equilibrium payoffs (Nisan et al., 2007).
    ${ }^{4}$ Note that it is not truly necessary to have $b_{t}^{i} \leq \varepsilon$. We can assume that there is a global constant $b$, such that all clients can add a mean-zero variance-one noise term scaled by at most $b$, and the condition becomes $b_{t}^{i} \leq b+\varepsilon$

where $C_{t}$ is some client-independent constant (see the individual results below for definition). The total payment for each client for the protocol is then $p_{i}=\sum_{i=1}^{T} p_{t}^{i}\left(\vec{m}_{t}\right)$. Note that this payment rule is budgetbalanced, that is at each step the server neither makes nor loses money because $\sum_{i=1}^{N} p_{t}^{i}\left(\vec{m}_{t}\right)=0$, so it is possible that some clients get paid while others get charged according to what update they communicate. The budget-balanced property guarantees that there are no conflicting incentives with the server, because the server makes no profit from the payment scheme. Moreover, the payments can be computed solely based on the clients' messages, so no additional communication is required.

# 5.1 Incentive compatibility and approximately truthful reporting 

First we show that the payment scheme is both $\varepsilon$-Bayesian Incentive Compatible and incentivizes approximately truthful reporting.
Theorem 5.1 (Properties of the payment scheme). For every client $i$, suppose their objective $F_{i}$ is $H$-smooth and $m$-strongly-convex, and their reward $R_{i}$ is L-Lipschitz. Set $C_{t}=\frac{\sqrt{35} \gamma_{i} L}{N \varepsilon}$, where $\mathcal{C}_{t}=\prod_{l=t+1}^{T} c_{l}$ and $c_{l}=2\left(1-2 \gamma_{l} m+\gamma_{l}^{2} H^{2}\right)$. Then

1. the FedSGD protocol with Payment Rule (1) is $\frac{\sqrt{2} L G \varepsilon}{2}-B I C$, where $G=\sum_{t=1}^{T} \gamma_{t} \sqrt{\mathcal{C}_{t}}$,
2. the best response strategy $\left(a_{t}^{i}, b_{t}^{i}\right)$ of client $i$ to truthful participation from everyone else satisfies $\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|a_{t}^{i} g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)-g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\right] \leq \varepsilon^{2}$ and $b_{t}^{i} \leq \varepsilon$ for all $t$.

Intuitively, the two results demonstrate that if all other players $j \neq i$ are truthful, then it is in the interest of player $i$ to be (approximately) truthful as well, and this will yield close to optimal utility. Note that above the variables $C_{t}$ and $\mathcal{C}_{t}$ depend on the learning rate, so for different learning schedules we get different payment values. In our experiments in Section 6 we instead use constant $C_{t}$ and still obtain positive results.

### 5.2 Payments and convergence

Next, we provide explicit upper bounds on the total penalty paid by each player, as well as on the convergence speed for the loss function of each client, whenever the clients are $\varepsilon$-approximately truthful. These bounds allow us to discuss the interplay between learning quality and penalties, as well as their dependence on the parameters of the FL protocol.
Theorem 5.2 (Bound on individual payments). Suppose all participants are reporting approximately truthfully at each time step. Then the total payment paid by client $i$ is bounded by

$$
\sum_{t=1}^{T} p_{t}^{i}\left(\vec{m}_{t}\right) \leq \frac{\sqrt{2} L G}{N}\left[2 \varepsilon^{2}+2 \varepsilon \sigma+2 \zeta^{2}+\rho^{2}\right]+\frac{\sqrt{8} L \varepsilon}{N} \sum_{t=1}^{T} \gamma_{t} \sqrt{\mathcal{C}_{t}}\left\|\nabla F_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|
$$

where $G=\sum_{t=1}^{T} \gamma_{t} \sqrt{\mathcal{C}_{t}}$.
Theorem 5.3 (Convergence rate). Suppose all players are reporting $\varepsilon$-approximately truthfully at each time step. Assume that there exist scalars $M \geq 0$ and $M_{V} \geq 0$, such that for every $t$ the gradient error is bounded by

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|e_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\right] \leq M+M_{V}\left\|\nabla F_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}
$$

Let $\eta=\frac{4 H\left(2 M_{V}+N\right)}{m N}$ and $\gamma_{t}=\frac{4}{m(\eta+t)}$. Then

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[F\left(\theta_{T}\right)-F\left(\theta^{*}\right)\right] \leq \max \left\{\frac{16 H\left(2 \varepsilon^{2}+M+M_{V} \zeta^{2}\right)}{3 N m^{2}(\eta+T)}, \frac{(\eta+1)\left(F\left(\theta_{1}\right)-F\left(\theta^{*}\right)\right)}{\eta+T}\right\}
$$

Discussion. The following two scenarios explore the effect of higher levels of heterogeneity on the expected payment of each player and the convergence rate of the federated learning protocol. In particular, we seek to understand what is the trade-off between heterogeneity and payments/convergence rate. Both of these directly rely on Theorems 5.1 and 5.3.

Example 5.4 (Constant heterogeneity bounds). Suppose $\zeta$ and $\rho$ are both constants fixed before the learning process is ever run. Then the total payment made by each player is at most $O\left(\frac{1}{N}\right)$ and the convergence rate becomes $O\left(\frac{1}{N T}\right)$. Hence, both the expected payments and the convergence rate decrease linearly in $N$, while preserving the $\varepsilon$-BIC property and the approximate truthful reporting property.
Example 5.5 (Scaling the heterogeneity bounds for large $N$ ). Notice that even if the heterogeneity bounds increase with the number of clients, our results still give reasonable bounds on the individual payments and the convergence rate. Suppose $\zeta$ and $\rho$ are both of order $O(\sqrt[4]{N})$. Then the total payment made by each player is at most $O\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{N}}\right)$ and the convergence rate becomes $O\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{N T}}\right)$. Hence, as we increase the number of participants $N$ we can simultaneously (1) increase the threshold for heterogeneity; and (2) reduce the maximal individual payment, while (3) preserving convergence.

# 5.3 Extensions of the action space 

This subsection presents several generalization of the strategy space we defined in Subsection 4. All three claims follow from our original theoretical analysis with slight modifications (see Appendix H for details).
Claim 5.6 (Mixed strategies). Suppose the message that client $i$ sends is $m_{t}^{i}=a_{t}^{i} g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)+b_{t}^{i} \xi_{t}^{i}$, where $a_{t}^{i}$ and $b_{t}^{i}$ are random variables, such that $\left|a_{t}^{i}\right| \geq 1$ almost surely and both variables are independent of the gradient updates and the protocol history. Then the results from Theorem 5.1, Proposition 5.2 and Theorem 5.3 still hold.

Claim 5.7 (History-dependent strategies). Suppose the message that client $i$ sends is $m_{t}^{i}=a_{t}^{i} g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)+b_{t}^{i} \xi_{t}^{i}$, where $a_{t}^{i}$ and $b_{t}^{i}$ are random variables, such that $\left|a_{t}^{i}\right| \geq 1$ almost surely and both variables are allowed to depend on the protocol history. Then the results from Theorem 5.1, Proposition 5.2 and Theorem 5.3 still hold.

Claim 5.8 (Directional strategies). Suppose the message that client $i$ sends is $m_{t}^{i}=h_{t}^{i}+b_{t}^{i} \xi_{t}^{i}$, where

- $h_{t}^{i}$ is a "gradient" vector, such that $\left\|h_{t}^{i}\right\|=a_{t}^{i} g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)$ and $\left\langle h_{t}^{i}, g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\rangle \geq\left\|g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2},{ }^{5}$
- $\xi_{t}^{i}$ is the additive noise term from before.

Then the results from Theorem 5.1, Proposition 5.2 and Theorem 5.3 still hold.

## 6 Experimental results

Finally, we present our experiments on three tasks from natural language processing and computer vision in an FL setting. Our goal is to evaluate the effectiveness of our payment scheme for FedSGD on non-convex, non-smooth objectives encountered in practice. Furthermore, we test the payment rule on a robust variant of FedSGD with coordinate-wise median aggregation and on the classic FedAvg protocol. Our results indicate that the incentives for gradient manipulation due to heterogeneity arise also in non-convex FL settings and that our payment mechanism is still successful in disincentivizing such manipulations from a client, provided that all others are truthful.

### 6.1 Tasks, data and training

Image classification. We use a two-layer Convolutional Neural Network. The first layer has 3 input channels and 32 output channels, while the second layer has 32 input channels and 64 output channels. Both layers apply a $5 \times 5$ kernel with stride 1 and padding 2 . After each layer we add ReLU activation and $2 \times 2$ max pooling with stride 2. We train on the FeMNIST dataset (Caldas et al., 2018) for $T=10650$ steps with constant learning rate $\gamma=0.06$.

Sentiment analysis. We use a two-layer linear classifier with 384 hidden neurons on top frozen BERT embeddings. We train on the Twitter dataset (Caldas et al., 2018) for $T=3550$ steps with constant learning rate $\gamma=0.06$.

# 6.2 Discussion 

We visualize our results for FedSGD in Figure 2. We plot the utility of the clients in $A$ versus the scaling factor $a_{A}$ they use to upscale their updates. Here $b_{A}=0$. The different curves correspond to the utility for different values of the penalty parameter $C$.

We see that our mechanism successfully disincentivizes gradient modification for the FeMNIST and Shakespeare datasets. This is because the utility of group $A$ decreases with $a_{A}$ for the curves with larger values of $C$, so the players in $A$ do not benefit from up-scaling their updates. For the Twitter dataset, the scaling factor is marginally beneficial to begin with, but the payment rule is still effective.

These results continue to hold for median-based FedSGD (see Figure 3a) and FedAvg (see Figure 3b). We note that the effects of gradient modification are smaller for median-based FedSGD compared to standard FedSGD and FedAvg, which is expected because coordinate-wise median aggregation has been used as a benchmark for robust aggregators (Pillutla et al., 2022).

We refer to Appendix J for results from additional experiments with median-based FedSGD and FedAvg, as well as experiments with varying noise levels (instead of scaling factors).

# 7 Conclusion 

In this work we showed that update manipulation incentives in federated learning can arise due to data heterogeneity, even without adversarial intent. To mitigate this, we introduced a game-theoretic framework and a budget-balanced payment mechanism that ensures approximate incentive compatibility and approximate truthful reporting. Empirical work confirmed the effectiveness of our method across multiple tasks and its adaptability to multiple FL protocols.

## Impact Statement

This paper presents work whose goal is to advance the field of Machine Learning. Our theoretical analysis contributes to better understanding of the impact of machine learning on society. Therefore, we expect that our results can serve a positive purpose in increasing the awareness about ML impact and encouraging further research on related topics. There are many potential societal consequences of our work, none which we feel must be specifically highlighted here.

## A Theoretical refresher

Definition A. 1 (Lipschitzness). A function $f: \mathcal{X} \subseteq \mathbb{R}^{n} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}^{m}$ is $L$-Lipschitz if

$$
\|f(x)-f(y)\|_{m} \leq L\|x-y\|_{n}
$$

for all $x, y \in \mathcal{X}$.
Definition A. 2 (Smoothness). A differentiable function $f: \mathcal{X} \subseteq \mathbb{R}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ is $H$-smooth if

$$
\|\nabla f(x)-\nabla f(y)\| \leq H\|x-y\|
$$

for all $x, y \in \mathcal{X}$. In other words, $f$ is $H$-smooth if its gradient $\nabla f$ is $H$-Lipschitz. Moreover, this condition is equivalent to

$$
|f(x)-f(y)-\langle\nabla f(y), x-y\rangle| \leq \frac{H}{2}\|x-y\|^{2}
$$

Definition A. 3 (Strong convexity). Let $f: \mathcal{X} \subseteq \mathbb{R}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ be a differentiable function. Then $f$ is $m$-stronglyconvex if

$$
f(x) \geq f(y)+\langle\nabla f(y), x-y\rangle+\frac{m}{2}\|x-y\|^{2}
$$

Proposition A.4. Let $f: \mathcal{X} \subseteq \mathbb{R}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$ be a differentiable function that is both $H$-smooth and $m$-stronglyconvex, then

$$
\frac{m}{2}\|x-y\|^{2} \leq f(x)-f(y)-\langle\nabla f(y), x-y\rangle \leq \frac{H}{2}\|x-y\|^{2}
$$

In other words, the error between $f$ and its linear approximation is bounded by quadratics from both above and below.

## B Heterogeneity assumptions from previous works

For this section assume we work on some space $\Theta \subseteq \mathbb{R}^{d}$. In the literature, many heterogeneity assumptions have been formulated mainly for the study of convergence of different flavors of distributed SGD (Koloskova et al., 2020; Woodworth et al., 2020; Patel et al., 2024). Our focus here is to compare Assumption 2.3 to the most relevant assumptions from the literature. To be the best our knowledge constraints similar to Assumption 2.4 that bound the heterogeneity of gradient variance have not been extensively studied.

Assumption B. 1 (Bounded First-Order Heterogeneity, (Koloskova et al., 2020; Woodworth et al., 2020)). For any client $i$ and any $\theta \in \Theta$ we have:

$$
\sup _{\theta \in \Theta, i \in[N]}\left\|\nabla F_{i}(\theta)-\nabla F(\theta)\right\|_{2}^{2} \leq \zeta^{2}
$$

Assumption B. 2 (Relaxed First-Order Heterogeneity, (Karimireddy et al., 2020)). There exist constants $G \geq 0$ and $D \geq 1$, such that for every $\theta \in \Theta$ the following holds:

$$
\frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^{N}\left\|\nabla F_{i}(\theta)\right\|^{2} \leq G^{2}+D^{2}\|\nabla F(\theta)\|^{2}
$$

One can interpret Assumption 2.3 as a relaxed version of Assumption B.1, where we ignore the angular (or directional) heterogeneity between two gradients, and only focus on their difference in magnitude. On the other hand, Assumption B. 2 relaxes Assumption 2.3 even further, by putting a constraint only on the average magnitude of the communicated gradients, as opposed to having a bound for each individual client. This positions our assumption in-between these two widely used heterogeneity constraints.
Remark. If Assumption B. 2 holds with $D=0$ and $\theta^{*} \in \underset{\theta \in \Theta}{\arg \min } F(\theta)$, then we recover another assumption used in the literature-Bounded First-Order Heterogeneity at Optima (Koloskova et al., 2020; Woodworth et al., 2020; Glasgow et al., 2022).

# C Note on Incentive Compatibility 

The usual definition of Bayesian Incentive Compatibility from Mechanism Design is the following. Suppose that each player $i$ has a true type $t_{i} \in T_{i}$, and a utility function $u_{i}(t, o)$ that takes as input a type $t$ and an outcome $o$, and outputs a value. Let $o\left(t_{i}, t_{-i}\right)$ be the outcome of the mechanism $M$ on input $\left(t_{i}, t_{-i}\right)$. Let $p_{i}\left(t_{i}, t_{-i}\right)$ be the payment of player $i$ according to $M$.
Definition C. 1 (Bayesian Incentive Compatibility). A mechanism $M$ is Bayesian Incentive Compatible (BIC) if:

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[u_{i}\left(t_{i}, o\left(t_{i}, t_{-i}\right)\right)-p_{i}\left(t_{i}, t_{-i}\right)\right] \geq \mathbb{E}\left[u_{i}\left(t_{i}, o\left(t_{i}^{\prime}, t_{-i}\right)\right)-p_{i}\left(t_{i}^{\prime}, t_{-i}\right)\right]
$$

where $t_{i}^{\prime} \in T_{i}$ is any type for player $i$, and expectation is taken with respect to the randomness in the types of everyone but player $i$.

Moreover, we can relax the condition to have an approximately BIC mechanism up to an additive constant, denoted $\varepsilon$-BIC:

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[u_{i}\left(t_{i}, o\left(t_{i}, t_{-i}\right)\right)-p_{i}\left(t_{i}, t_{-i}\right)\right] \geq \mathbb{E}\left[u_{i}\left(t_{i}, o\left(t_{i}, t_{-i}\right)\right)-p_{i}\left(t_{i}^{\prime}, t_{-i}\right)\right]-\varepsilon
$$

## D Results on Mean Estimation
## D. 1 Proof of Proposition 3.1

One can easily check that if the first player is truthful, then the MSE is as stated. Now, consider the case where the first client can lie by selecting a constant $c>1$. In particular, if we select a constant $c$ such that

$$
1<c<\frac{2 \mu_{1}\left(\mu_{1}-\mu\right) N+\mu_{1}^{2}-\sigma^{2}}{\mu_{1}^{2}+\sigma^{2}}
$$

then the we have $\mathbb{E}[\bar{\mu}]=\frac{c-1}{N} \mu_{1}+\mu$ and $\operatorname{Var}(\bar{\mu})=\frac{\sigma^{2}}{N}+\frac{c^{2}-1}{N^{2}} \sigma^{2}$. Then the MSE for the first player is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\bar{\mu}-\mu_{1}\right)^{2}\right] & =\left(\mu+\frac{c-N-1}{N} \mu_{1}\right)^{2}+\frac{\sigma^{2}}{N}+\frac{c^{2}-1}{N^{2}} \sigma^{2} \\
& =\left(\mu-\mu_{1}\right)^{2}+2 \frac{c-1}{N} \mu_{1}\left(\mu-\mu_{1}\right)+\frac{(c-1)^{2}}{N^{2}} \mu_{1}^{2}+\frac{c^{2}-1}{N^{2}} \sigma^{2}+\frac{\sigma^{2}}{N} \\
& =\left(\mu-\mu_{1}\right)^{2}+\frac{\sigma^{2}}{N}+\frac{c-1}{N^{2}}\left(2 \mu_{1}\left(\mu-\mu_{1}\right) N+(c-1) \mu_{1}^{2}+(c+1) \sigma^{2}\right) \\
& =\left(\mu-\mu_{1}\right)^{2}+\frac{\sigma^{2}}{N}+\frac{c-1}{N^{2}}\left(c\left(\mu_{1}^{2}+\sigma^{2}\right)-2 \mu_{1}\left(\mu_{1}-\mu\right) N-\mu_{1}^{2}+\sigma^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Note that the last term is a quadratic in $c$ and hence is minimized at

$$
c=\frac{\mu_{1}^{2}+\mu_{1}\left(\mu_{1}-\mu\right) N}{\mu_{1}^{2}+\sigma^{2}}>1
$$

Note that $c>1$ is guaranteed by the assumed inequality $\mu_{1}\left(\mu_{1}-\mu\right)>\sigma^{2} / N$. In this case, the MSE of the client is

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\bar{\mu}-\mu_{1}\right)^{2}\right]=\left(\mu-\mu_{1}\right)^{2}+\frac{\sigma^{2}}{N}-\frac{\left(\sigma^{2} / N-\mu_{1}\left(\mu_{1}-\mu\right)\right)^{2}}{\mu_{1}^{2}+\sigma^{2}}
$$

which completes our proof.

# D. 2 Individually optimal estimators without strategic actions 

Similarly to Proposition 3.1, suppose that $N$ clients seek to estimate their respective means $\mu_{1}, \ldots, \mu_{N} \in \mathbb{R}$ sampled from a prior $\mu_{i} \sim \mathcal{N}(\mu, 1 / \tau)$, where $\mu \sim \mathcal{N}\left(0,1 / \tau_{0}\right)$. Furthermore, assume that each client $i$ receives samples $\forall j \in[n] x_{i}^{j} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(\mu_{i}, \sigma_{i}^{2}\right)$. First, we want to understand how much clients could benefit from each other's samples in this Bayesian setting.

Proposition D.1. Consider $N$ clients who seek to find estimators $\left\{\hat{\mu}_{i}\right\}_{i=1}^{N}$ for their local parameters $\left\{\mu_{i}\right\}_{i=1}^{N}$ that are good in terms of mean squared error $\left(\bar{\mu}_{i}-\mu_{i}\right)^{2}$. Each client $i$ has $n$ independent noisy observations of $\mu_{i}$, such that $x_{i}^{j} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(\mu_{i}, \sigma_{i}^{2}\right)$ for every $j \in[n]$ and $i \in[N]$. Moreover, we assume that $\left\{\mu_{i}\right\}_{i=1}^{N}$ are related to each other through a prior $\mu_{i} \sim \mathcal{N}(\mu, 1 / \tau)$, and the prior mean is distributed as $\mu \sim \mathcal{N}\left(0,1 / \tau_{0}\right)$. Given all samples, the means follow

$$
\mu_{i} \sim \mathcal{N}\left(\frac{\tau_{i} \bar{x}_{i}+\beta_{i} \sum_{j \neq i} \rho_{j} \bar{x}_{j}}{\tau_{i}+\beta_{i}\left(\sum_{j \neq i} \rho_{j}+\tau_{0}\right)},\left(\tau_{i}+\beta_{i}\left(\sum_{j \neq i} \rho_{j}+\tau_{0}\right)\right)^{-1}\right)
$$

where $\tau_{j}=\frac{n}{\sigma_{j}^{2}}, \rho_{j}=\frac{\tau \tau_{j}}{\tau+\tau_{j}}$, and $\beta_{i}=\frac{\tau}{\sum_{j \neq i} \rho_{j}+\tau+\tau_{0}}$.
Proof. To derive the distribution of $\mu_{i}$, we should integrate the probability density function $f$ over $\mu,\left\{\mu_{j}\right\}_{j \neq i}$. This function is proportional to

$$
f \propto \exp \left(\sum_{j=1}^{N}-\frac{\tau_{j}\left(\bar{x}_{j}-\mu_{j}\right)^{2}}{2}+\sum_{j=1}^{N}-\frac{\tau\left(\mu_{j}-\mu\right)^{2}}{2}-\frac{\tau_{0} \mu^{2}}{2}\right)
$$

First, we want to integrate over $\left\{\mu_{j}\right\}_{j \neq i}$. By collecting the terms relevant to $\mu_{j}$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
-\frac{\tau_{j}\left(\bar{x}_{j}-\mu_{j}\right)^{2}}{2}-\frac{\tau\left(\mu_{j}-\mu\right)^{2}}{2} & =-\frac{\tau_{j}\left(\bar{x}_{j}^{2}-2 \bar{x}_{j} \mu_{j}+\mu_{j}^{2}\right)}{2}-\frac{\tau\left(\mu_{j}^{2}-2 \mu_{j} \mu+\mu^{2}\right)}{2} \\
& =-\frac{\left(\tau_{j}+\tau\right) \mu_{j}^{2}}{2}+\left(\tau_{j} \bar{x}_{j}+\tau \mu\right) \mu_{j}-\frac{\tau_{j} \bar{x}_{j}^{2}}{2}-\frac{\tau \mu^{2}}{2} \\
& =-\frac{\left(\tau_{j}+\tau\right)\left(\mu_{j}-\frac{\tau_{j} \bar{x}_{j}+\tau \mu}{\tau_{j}+\tau}\right)^{2}}{2}+\frac{\left(\tau_{j} \bar{x}_{j}+\tau \mu\right)^{2}}{2\left(\tau_{j}+\tau\right)}-\frac{\tau_{j} \bar{x}_{j}^{2}}{2}-\frac{\tau \mu^{2}}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{\left(\tau_{j} \bar{x}_{j}+\tau \mu\right)^{2}}{2\left(\tau_{j}+\tau\right)}-\frac{\tau_{j} \bar{x}_{j}^{2}}{2}-\frac{\tau \mu^{2}}{2} & =\frac{\left(\tau_{j} \bar{x}_{j}\right)^{2}+2 \tau \tau_{j} \bar{x}_{j} \mu+\tau^{2} \mu^{2}}{2\left(\tau_{j}+\tau\right)}-\frac{\tau_{j} \bar{x}_{j}^{2}}{2}-\frac{\tau \mu^{2}}{2} \\
& =-\frac{\rho_{j} \mu^{2}}{2}+\rho_{j} \bar{x}_{j} \mu-\frac{\rho_{j} \bar{x}_{j}^{2}}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, after integrating over $\mu_{j}$, we get that the density function $f$ will be proportional to

$$
f \propto \exp \left(\sum_{j \neq i}\left(-\frac{\rho_{j} \mu^{2}}{2}+\rho_{j} \bar{x}_{j} \mu-\frac{\rho_{j} \bar{x}_{j}^{2}}{2}\right)-\frac{\tau_{i}\left(\bar{x}_{i}-\mu_{i}\right)^{2}}{2}-\frac{\tau\left(\mu_{i}-\mu\right)^{2}}{2}-\frac{\tau_{0} \mu^{2}}{2}\right)
$$

Now, we want to integrate over $\mu$. By collecting the terms relevant to $\mu$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
-\frac{\tau\left(\mu_{i}-\mu\right)^{2}}{2}-\frac{\tau_{0} \mu^{2}}{2}+\sum_{j \neq i}-\frac{\rho_{j} \mu^{2}}{2}+\rho_{j} \bar{x}_{j} \mu & =-\frac{\left(\tau+\tau_{0}+\sum_{j \neq i} \rho_{j}\right) \mu^{2}}{2}+\left(\tau \mu_{i}+\sum_{j \neq i} \rho_{j} \bar{x}_{j}\right) \mu-\frac{\tau \mu_{i}^{2}}{2} \\
& =-\frac{\left(\tau+\tau_{0}+\sum_{j \neq i} \rho_{j}\right)\left(\mu-\frac{\tau \mu_{i}+\sum_{j \neq i} \rho_{j} \bar{x}_{j}}{\tau+\tau_{0}+\sum_{j \neq i} \rho_{j}}\right)^{2}}{2}+\frac{\left(\tau \mu_{i}+\sum_{j \neq i} \rho_{j} \bar{x}_{j}\right)^{2}}{2\left(\tau+\tau_{0}+\sum_{j \neq i} \rho_{j}\right)}-\frac{\tau \mu_{i}^{2}}{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, the final density will be proportional to

$$
\begin{aligned}
f & \propto \exp \left(\frac{\left(\tau \mu_{i}+\sum_{j \neq i} \rho_{j} \bar{x}_{j}\right)^{2}}{2\left(\tau+\tau_{0}+\sum_{j \neq i} \rho_{j}\right)}-\frac{\tau \mu_{i}^{2}}{2}-\frac{\tau_{i}\left(\bar{x}_{i}-\mu_{i}\right)^{2}}{2}\right) \\
& =\exp \left(-\frac{\mu_{i}^{2} \cdot\left(\frac{\tau\left(\tau_{0}+\sum_{j \neq i} \rho_{j}\right)}{\tau+\tau_{0}+\sum_{j \neq i} \rho_{j}}+\tau_{i}\right)}{2}+\left(\tau_{i} \bar{x}_{i}+\frac{\tau \sum_{j \neq i} \rho_{j} \bar{x}_{j}}{\tau+\tau_{0}+\sum_{j \neq i} \rho_{j}}\right) \mu_{i}+\ldots\right) \\
& =\exp \left(-\frac{\left(\tau_{i}+\beta_{i}\left(\tau_{0}+\sum_{j \neq i} \rho_{j}\right)\right)\left(\mu_{i}-\frac{\tau_{i} \bar{x}_{i}+\beta_{i} \sum_{j \neq i} \rho_{j} \bar{x}_{j}}{\tau_{i}+\beta_{i}\left(\tau_{0}+\sum_{j \neq i} \rho_{j}\right)}\right)^{2}}{2}+\ldots\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

which gives us the desired conditional distribution of $\mu_{i}$.

# Variance reduction incentives 

First, notice in the absence of heterogeneity, clients are not adverse to each other. To see it, consider the situation when the means of all clients are the same, $\tau \rightarrow \infty$. In this situation, individually optimal estimators converge to the same estimator

$$
\hat{\mu}^{*}=\frac{\sum_{j=1}^{N} \tau_{j} \bar{x}_{j}}{\tau_{0}+\sum_{j=1}^{N} \tau_{j}}
$$

This estimator is the best estimator for $\mu$ in the Bayesian setting. Thus, in the absence of heterogeneity, the clients want cooperate with each other to reduce the variance of individual estimators.

## Bias personalization incentives

However, if heterogeneity is present, the clients will also want to skew bias of the estimator closer to their mean. To see this effect, consider the situation when variance reduction incentives are symmetric, $\tau_{i}=\tau_{j}$ for all $i, j$. In this situation, we might notice that the weight of a client's own samples becomes bigger than the weight the samples of any other client in the individually optimal estimator,

$$
\tau_{i}=\tau_{j}>\beta_{i} \rho_{j}
$$

Thus, in the presence of heterogeneity, the clients want to increase the weight of the own samples in the final model, which will bias the final model closer to their own mean.

# D. 3 Nash equilibrium in the presence of scaling attacks 

Now, we consider a game-theoretic setting, where each client $i$ sends a message $m_{i}=\frac{c_{i}}{n} \sum_{j=1}^{n} x_{i}^{j}$ to the server. Then, the server computes an aggregate $\bar{\mu}=\frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^{N} m_{i}$ and broadcasts it to all clients. Each client $i$ would like to receive an estimate of their local mean with minimal mean squared error $\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\bar{\mu}-\mu_{i}\right)^{2}\right]$.
Proposition D.2. The Nash equilibrium of the game above is

$$
c_{i}^{\mathrm{eq}}=\frac{N \rho_{i}\left(1 / \tau+1 / \tau_{0}\right)}{1+\left(\sum_{j=1}^{N} \rho_{j}\right) / \tau_{0}}
$$

which results in the following final error:

$$
-R_{i}^{\mathrm{eq}}=\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\bar{\mu}-\mu^{i}\right)^{2}\right]=\frac{\left(1 / \tau+1 / \tau_{0}\right)\left(\sum_{j=1}^{N} \rho_{j}-2 \rho_{i}+\tau\right)}{\tau\left(1+\sum_{j=1}^{N} \rho_{j} / \tau_{0}\right)}
$$

Proof. Given actions profile, the error of client $i$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\bar{\mu}-\mu_{i}\right)^{2}\right] & =\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\sum_{j=1}^{N} \frac{c_{j}}{N} \bar{x}_{j}-\mu_{i}\right)^{2}\right] \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\sum_{j=1}^{N} \frac{c_{j}}{N}\left(\bar{x}_{j}-\mu_{j}\right)+\sum_{j=1}^{N} \frac{c_{j}}{N} \mu_{j}-\mu_{i}\right)^{2}\right] \\
& =\sum_{j=1}^{N} \frac{\left(c_{j}\right)^{2}}{N^{2} \tau_{j}}+\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\sum_{j=1}^{N} \frac{c_{j}}{N} \mu_{j}-\mu_{i}\right)^{2}\right] \\
& =\sum_{j=1}^{N} \frac{\left(c_{j}\right)^{2}}{N^{2} \tau_{j}}+\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\sum_{j \neq i} \frac{c_{j}}{N}\left(\mu_{j}-\mu\right)+\left(\mu_{i}-\mu\right) \cdot\left(\frac{c_{i}}{N}-1\right)+\mu \cdot\left(\frac{\sum_{j=1}^{N} c_{j}}{N}-1\right)\right)^{2}\right] \\
& =\sum_{j=1}^{N} \frac{\left(c_{j}\right)^{2}}{N^{2} \tau_{j}}+\frac{\sum_{j \neq i}\left(c_{j}\right)^{2}}{N^{2} \tau}+\frac{1}{\tau} \cdot\left(\frac{c_{i}}{N}-1\right)^{2}+\frac{1}{\tau_{0}} \cdot\left(\frac{\sum_{j=1}^{N} c_{j}}{N}-1\right)^{2} \\
& =\sum_{j=1}^{N} \frac{\left(c_{j}\right)^{2}}{N^{2} \rho_{j}}+\frac{\left(\sum_{j=1}^{N} c_{j}\right)^{2}}{N^{2} \tau_{0}}-\frac{2 c_{i}}{N \tau}-\frac{2 \sum_{j=1}^{N} c_{j}}{N \tau_{0}}+\frac{1}{\tau}+\frac{1}{\tau_{0}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, the best response of client $i$ satisfies

$$
\frac{c_{i}^{*}}{\rho_{i}}+\frac{c_{i}^{*}}{\tau_{0}}+\frac{\sum_{j \neq i} c_{j}}{\tau_{0}}=\frac{N}{\tau}+\frac{N}{\tau_{0}}
$$

So, in equilibrium, for every client $i$ we get

$$
\frac{c_{i}^{\mathrm{eq}}}{\rho_{i}}+\frac{\sum_{j=1}^{N} c_{j}^{\mathrm{eq}}}{\tau_{0}}=\frac{N}{\tau}+\frac{N}{\tau_{0}}
$$

Thus, $c_{i}^{\text {eq }}=\rho_{i} \lambda$ and

$$
\left(1+\frac{\sum_{j=1}^{N} \rho_{j}}{\tau_{0}}\right) \cdot \lambda=\frac{N}{\tau}+\frac{N}{\tau_{0}}
$$

which gives us the desired formula.

Penalty from personalization incentives Notice that, in the case of truthful reporting, we get

$$
-R_{i}^{0}=\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\bar{\mu}-\mu_{i}\right)^{2}\right]=\frac{1}{N}\left(\sum_{j=1}^{N} \frac{1}{\rho_{j}}-\frac{2}{\tau}\right)+\frac{1}{\tau}
$$

In the limit $N \rightarrow \infty$, we get

$$
-R_{i}^{\mathrm{eq}} \rightarrow \frac{1}{\tau}+\frac{\tau_{0}}{\tau^{2}},-R_{i}^{0} \rightarrow \frac{1}{\tau}+\frac{1}{N} \sum_{j=1}^{N} \frac{1}{\rho_{j}}
$$

Thus, in the case $\forall j \tau^{2}+\tau_{j} \tau<\tau_{j} \tau_{0}$ (i.e., when the heterogeneity between the means of the clients is high), the equilibrium actions of the clients result in a larger error compared to the truthful reporting. Notice that the penalty to the reward increases quadratically with the variance of heterogeneous means $\tau$. The clients suffer a big utility loss when the heterogeneity between their distributions is big.

Equilibrium in the absence of heterogeneity In the absence of heterogeneity (i.e., $\tau \rightarrow \infty$ ), we get

$$
c_{i}^{\mathrm{eq}} \rightarrow \frac{N \tau_{i}}{\tau_{0}+\sum_{j=1}^{N} \tau_{j}}
$$

which are exactly the weights for the best estimator in Bayesian setting. Thus, as we predicted in the previous subsection, in the absence of heterogeneity, the clients do not have adverse incentives and collaborate with each other to reduce the variance of their estimators.

Equilibrium in the case of homogeneous data quality When the quality of local data is the same for each client $\left(\tau_{i}=\tau_{j}\right.$ for all $\left.i, j\right)$, the formula for the equilibrium weight simplifies

$$
c_{i}^{\mathrm{eq}}=\frac{1+\tau_{0} / \tau}{1+\tau_{0} /(N \rho)}
$$

Here, we can see how bias personalization and variance reduction incentives interact. When the quality of data is poor ( $\rho$ is small), $c_{i}^{\text {eq }}$ also becomes small. The clients are not incentivized to skew model closer to their local mean because they can not estimate the personal bias well. Instead, they want to rely more on the data of others and global prior to reduce the variance of their estimator. On the other hand, when the quality of data is high ( $\rho$ is big), $c_{i}^{\text {eq }}$ becomes bigger than 1 . The clients want to skew the global model in their favor. However, the size of this skew is limited because the clients do not want the global model to diverge.

# E Proof of Theorem 5.1 

We start with a summary of the results in this section. A trajectory is the history of models produced by the FL protocol, i.e. the sequence $\theta_{1}, \theta_{2}, \ldots, \theta_{T+1}$. Combining all claims here establishes Theorem 5.1.

- Claim E. 1 bounds the step-wise difference between two model trajectories, produced by different strategies.
- Claim E. 2 bounds the difference in total reward achieved at time $T+1$, i.e. the reward from the final model, between two trajectories.
- Claim E. 3 bounds the difference
- Proposition E. 4 combines the previous to show that under our payment scheme (with a good choice of constant $C_{t}$ ) the optimal per-step strategy for client $i$, when everyone else is truthful, is $\varepsilon$-close to the true one.
- Claim E. 5 extends the previous result to the full run of the protocol.
- Combining the previous yields Theorem 5.1

Claim E. 1 (Per-turn bound on trajectory difference). Fix a client $i$. Let $\theta=\left\{\theta_{t}\right\}_{t=1}^{T+1}$ and $\theta^{\prime}=\left\{\theta_{t}^{\prime}\right\}_{t=1}^{T+1}$, be two trajectories obtained from two distinct strategy profiles $\left\{a_{t}^{i}\right\}_{t=1}^{T}$ and $\left\{\bar{a}_{t}^{i}\right\}_{t=1}^{T}$ of client $i$, while everyone else is implementing the same strategy in both scenarios. Then at time $t+1$ conditioned on the event that $\left\|\theta_{t+1}-\theta_{t+1}^{\prime}\right\|^{2} \geq \varepsilon$ we have:

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\theta_{t+1}-\theta_{t+1}^{\prime}\right\|^{2}\right] \leq c_{t} \mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\theta_{t}-\theta_{t}^{\prime}\right\|^{2}\right]+\frac{2 \gamma_{t}^{2}}{N^{2}} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(a_{t}^{i}-\bar{a}_{t}^{i}\right)^{2}\left\|g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}^{\prime}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]+\frac{\gamma_{t}^{2}\left(b_{t}^{i}-\bar{b}_{t}^{i}\right)^{2}}{N^{2}}
$$

where $c_{t}=2\left(1-\frac{2 \gamma_{t} m A_{t}}{N}+\frac{\gamma_{t}^{2} A_{t}^{2} H^{2}}{N^{2}}\right)$ and $A_{t}=\sum_{j=1}^{N} a_{t}^{j}$.
Proof. Observe the following sequence

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\theta_{t+1}-\theta_{t+1}^{\prime}\right\|^{2}\right] & =\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\left(\theta_{t}-\theta_{t}^{\prime}\right)-\gamma_{t}\left(\bar{m}_{t}-\bar{m}_{t}^{\prime}\right)\right\|^{2}\right] \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\left(\theta_{t}-\theta_{t}^{\prime}\right)-\frac{\gamma_{t}}{N} \sum_{j=1}^{N}\left(a_{t}^{j} g_{j}\left(\theta_{t}\right)-\bar{a}_{t}^{j} g_{j}\left(\theta_{t}^{\prime}\right)+b_{t}^{j} \xi_{t}^{i}-\bar{b}_{t}^{i} \bar{\xi}_{t}^{i}\right)\right\|^{2}\right] \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\frac{\left(\bar{a}_{t}^{i}-a_{t}^{i}\right) \gamma_{t}}{N} g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}^{\prime}\right)+\left(\theta_{t}-\theta_{t}^{\prime}\right)-\frac{\gamma_{t}}{N} \sum_{j=1}^{N} a_{t}^{j}\left(g_{j}\left(\theta_{t}\right)-g_{j}\left(\theta_{t}^{\prime}\right)\right)\right\|^{2}\right]+\frac{\gamma_{t}^{2}\left(b_{t}^{i}-\bar{b}_{t}^{i}\right)^{2}}{N^{2}} \\
& \leq 2 \mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\frac{\left(\bar{a}_{t}^{i}-a_{t}^{i}\right) \gamma_{t}}{N} g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}^{\prime}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]+2 \mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\left(\theta_{t}-\theta_{t}^{\prime}\right)-\frac{\gamma_{t}}{N} \sum_{j=1}^{N} a_{t}^{j}\left(g_{j}\left(\theta_{t}\right)-g_{j}\left(\theta_{t}^{\prime}\right)\right)\right\|^{2}\right]+\frac{\gamma_{t}^{2}\left(b_{t}^{i}-\bar{b}_{t}^{i}\right)^{2}}{N^{2}} \\
& \leq 2 \mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\left(\theta_{t}-\theta_{t}^{\prime}\right)-\frac{\gamma_{t}}{N} \sum_{j=1}^{N} a_{t}^{j}\left(g_{j}\left(\theta_{t}\right)-g_{j}\left(\theta_{t}^{\prime}\right)\right)\right\|^{2}\right]+\frac{2 \gamma_{t}^{2}\left(a_{t}^{i}-\bar{a}_{t}^{i}\right)^{2} \mathbb{E}\left[\left\|g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}^{\prime}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]}{N^{2}}+\frac{\gamma_{t}^{2}\left(b_{t}^{i}-\bar{b}_{t}^{i}\right)^{2}}{N^{2}} \\
& =2 \mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\theta_{t}-\theta_{t}^{\prime}\right\|^{2}\right]+2 \mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\frac{\gamma_{t}}{N} \sum_{j=1}^{N} a_{t}^{j}\left(g_{j}\left(\theta_{t}\right)-g_{j}\left(\theta_{t}^{\prime}\right)\right)\right\|^{2}\right] \\
& -4 \mathbb{E}\left[\frac{\gamma_{t}}{N} \sum_{j=1}^{N} a_{t}^{j}\left\langle\theta_{t}-\theta_{t}^{\prime}, g_{j}\left(\theta_{t}\right)-g_{j}\left(\theta_{t}^{\prime}\right)\right\rangle\right]+\frac{2 \gamma_{t}^{3}\left(a_{t}^{i}-\bar{a}_{t}^{i}\right)^{2} \mathbb{E}\left[\left\|g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}^{\prime}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]}{N^{2}}+\frac{\gamma_{t}^{2}\left(b_{t}^{i}-\bar{b}_{t}^{i}\right)^{2}}{N^{2}} \\
& \leq 2 \mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\theta_{t}-\theta_{t}^{\prime}\right\|^{2}\right]+\frac{2 \gamma_{t}^{2} A_{t}^{2} H^{2}}{N^{2}} \mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\theta_{t}-\theta_{t}^{\prime}\right\|^{2}\right]-\frac{4 \gamma_{t} m A_{t}}{N} \mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\theta_{t}-\theta_{t}^{\prime}\right\|^{2}\right] \\
& +\frac{2 \gamma_{t}^{2} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(a_{t}^{i}-\bar{a}_{t}^{i}\right)^{2}\left\|g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}^{\prime}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]}{N^{2}}+\frac{\gamma_{t}^{2}\left(b_{t}^{i}-\bar{b}_{t}^{i}\right)^{2}}{N^{2}} \\
& =2\left(1-\frac{2 \gamma_{t} m A_{t}}{N}+\frac{\gamma_{t}^{2} A_{t}^{2} H^{2}}{N^{2}}\right) \mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\theta_{t}-\theta_{t}^{\prime}\right\|^{2}\right]+\frac{2 \gamma_{t}^{2}}{N^{2}} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(a_{t}^{i}-\bar{a}_{t}^{i}\right)^{2}\left\|g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}^{\prime}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]+\frac{\gamma_{t}^{2}\left(b_{t}^{i}-\bar{b}_{t}^{i}\right)^{2}}{N^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

The first three lines are rearrangement. The third line uses the fact that both $\xi_{t}^{i}$ and $\bar{\xi}_{t}^{i}$ are have mean zero and variance one. The forth line uses the inequality $(x+y)^{2} \leq 2 x^{2}+2 y^{2}$. ${ }^{7}$ On line seven (second to last inequality), the second term follows from $H$-smoothness of the loss function for the sample $z_{t}^{j}$ of client $j$ at time $t$, while the third term follows from the $m$-strong-convexity of $F_{i}$.
