[^0]:    ${ }^{7}$ We do this roundabout bounding, so that all terms are squared norms. Also notice that $(x+y)^{2} \leq 2 x^{2}+2 y^{2}$ is equivalent to $0 \leq(x-y)^{2}$, which is trivially true.

Corollary 1 (Bound on trajectory difference). Suppose that $\theta=\left\{\theta_{t}\right\}_{t=1}^{T+1}$ is obtained from fully truthful participation from all clients, i.e. $\left(a_{t}^{\prime}, b_{t}^{\prime}\right)=(1,0)$. Then at time $T+1$ :

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\theta_{T+1}-\theta_{T+1}^{\prime}\right\|^{2}\right] \leq \frac{2}{N^{2}} \sum_{t=1}^{T} \gamma_{t}^{2} \mathcal{C}_{t}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\bar{a}_{t}^{\prime}-1\right)^{2}\left\|g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}^{\prime}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]+\left(\bar{b}_{t}^{\prime}\right)^{2}\right)
$$

where $\mathcal{C}_{t}=\prod_{l=t+1}^{T} c_{l}$ and $c_{l}=2\left(1-2 \gamma_{l} m+\gamma_{l}^{2} H^{2}\right)$.
Proof. Apply Claim E. 1 and telescope. Because the reference strategy is all truthful reporting, then we have $A=N$ in Claim E.1.

Claim E. 2 (Bound on reward). Suppose that $\theta=\left\{\theta_{t}\right\}_{t=1}^{T+1}$ is obtained from fully truthful participation from all clients. Then at time $T+1$ :

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\left|R_{i}\left(\theta_{T+1}\right)-R_{i}\left(\theta_{T+1}^{\prime}\right)\right|\right] \leq \frac{\sqrt{2} L}{N} \sum_{t=1}^{T} \gamma_{t} \sqrt{\mathcal{C}}_{t}\left(\sqrt{\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\bar{a}_{t}^{\prime}-1\right)^{2}\left\|g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}^{\prime}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]}+\left|\bar{b}_{t}^{\prime}\right|\right)
$$

where $\mathcal{C}_{t}=\prod_{t^{\prime}=1}^{t} c_{t^{\prime}}$ and $c_{l}=2\left(1-2 \gamma_{l} m+\gamma_{l}^{2} H^{2}\right)$.
Proof. Observe:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\left|R_{i}\left(\theta_{T+1}\right)-R_{i}\left(\theta_{T+1}^{\prime}\right)\right|\right]\right)^{2} & \leq L^{2}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\theta_{T+1}-\theta_{T+1}^{\prime}\right\|\right]\right)^{2} \\
& \leq L^{2} \mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\theta_{T+1}-\theta_{T+1}^{\prime}\right\|^{2}\right] \\
& \leq L^{2} \mathcal{C}_{0} \mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\theta_{1}-\theta_{t}^{\prime}\right\|^{2}\right]+\frac{2 L^{2}}{N^{2}} \sum_{t=1}^{T} \gamma_{t}^{2} \mathcal{C}_{t}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\bar{a}_{t}^{\prime}-1\right)^{2}\left\|g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}^{\prime}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]+\left(\bar{b}_{t}^{\prime}\right)^{2}\right) \\
& =\frac{2 L^{2}}{N^{2}} \sum_{t=1}^{T} \gamma_{t}^{2} \mathcal{C}_{t}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\bar{a}_{t}^{\prime}-1\right)^{2}\left\|g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}^{\prime}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]+\left(\bar{b}_{t}^{\prime}\right)^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

The first line follows from $F_{i}(\cdot)$ being $L$-Lipschitz. The second line follows from Cauchy-Schwartz. The third line applies Corollary 1, and uses the assumption $\theta_{1}=\theta_{1}^{\prime}$. Finally, to get the desired inequality we observe that $\sqrt{x+y} \leq \sqrt{x}+\sqrt{y}$ for non-negative $x, y$.

Claim E. 3 (Bound on payment). Suppose $\theta$ and $\theta^{\prime}$ are such that (1) they coincide exactly for the first $t-1$ steps, (2) they differ in the strategy used by client $i$ at time $t$, so $\left(a_{t}^{\prime}, b_{t}^{\prime}\right)=(1,0)$ and $\bar{a}_{t}^{\prime} \geq 1$, and (3) all clients are truthful for all step $>t$. Then

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[p_{t}^{\prime}\left(\vec{m}_{t}\right)-p_{t}^{\prime}\left(\vec{m}_{t}^{\prime}\right)\right] \leq-C_{t} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\bar{a}_{t}^{\prime}-1\right)^{2}\left\|g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]-C_{t}\left(\bar{b}_{t}^{\prime}\right)^{2}
$$

Proof. For what's to follow keep in mind that $\bar{a}_{t}^{\prime} \geq 1$ by assumption, and the additive noise is mean zero and variance one. Observe:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[p_{t}^{\prime}\left(\vec{m}_{t}\right)-p_{t}^{\prime}\left(\vec{m}_{t}^{\prime}\right)\right]= & C_{t} \mathbb{E}\left[\left\|g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]-C_{t} \mathbb{E}\left[\frac{1}{N-1} \sum_{j \neq i}\left\|g_{j}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\right] \\
& -C_{t} \mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\bar{a}_{t}^{\prime} g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)+\bar{b}_{t}^{\prime} \xi_{i}^{t}\right\|^{2}\right]+C_{t} \mathbb{E}\left[\frac{1}{N-1} \sum_{j \neq i}\left\|g_{j}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\right] \\
= & C_{t} \mathbb{E}\left[\left\|g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]-C_{t} \mathbb{E}\left[\frac{1}{N-1} \sum_{j \neq i}\left\|g_{j}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \quad-C_{t} \mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\bar{a}_{t}^{i} g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]-C_{t}\left(\bar{b}_{t}^{i}\right)^{2}+C_{t} \mathbb{E}\left[\frac{1}{N-1} \sum_{j \neq i}\left\|g_{j}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\right] \\
= & C_{t} \mathbb{E}\left[\left\|g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]-C_{t} \mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\bar{a}_{t}^{i} g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]-C_{t}\left(\bar{b}_{t}^{i}\right)^{2} \\
= & C_{t} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(1-\left(\bar{a}_{t}^{i}\right)^{2}\right)\left\|g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]-C_{t}\left(\bar{b}_{t}^{i}\right)^{2} \\
\leq & -C_{t} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\bar{a}_{t}^{i}-1\right)^{2}\left\|g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]-C_{t}\left(\bar{b}_{t}^{i}\right)^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

The last line follows from the assumption $\bar{a}_{t}^{i} \geq 1$.
Proposition E. 4 (Bound on utility difference between trajectories). Suppose $\theta$ and $\theta^{\prime}$ are such that (1) they coincide exactly for the first $t-1$ steps, (2) they differ in the strategy used by client $i$ at time $t$, so $\left(a_{t}^{i}, b_{t}^{i}\right)=(1,0)$ and $\bar{a}_{t}^{i}>1$, and (3) all clients are truthful for all step $>t$. Then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[R_{i}\left(\theta_{t+1}^{\prime}\right)-p_{t}^{i}\left(\vec{m}_{t}^{\prime}\right)-\left(R_{i}\left(\theta_{t+1}\right)-p_{t}^{i}\left(\vec{m}_{t}\right)\right)\right] \leq & \frac{\sqrt{2 \mathcal{C}_{t}} \gamma_{t} L}{N}\left(\sqrt{\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\bar{a}_{t}^{i}-1\right)^{2}\left\|g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]}+\left|\bar{b}_{t}^{i}\right|\right) \\
& -C_{t}\left(\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\bar{a}_{t}^{i}-1\right)^{2}\left\|g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]+\left(\bar{b}_{t}^{i}\right)^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Moreover, for $C_{t}=\frac{\sqrt{2 \mathcal{C}_{t}} \gamma_{t} L}{N \varepsilon}$ we have:

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[R_{i}\left(\theta_{T}^{\prime}\right)-p_{t}^{i}\left(\vec{m}_{t}^{\prime}\right)-\left(R_{i}\left(\theta_{T}\right)-p_{t}^{i}\left(\vec{m}_{t}\right)\right)\right] \leq \frac{\sqrt{2 \mathcal{C}_{t}} \gamma_{t} L \varepsilon}{N}
$$

and the best strategy of client $i$ is such that $\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\bar{a}_{t}^{i} g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)-g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\right] \leq \varepsilon^{2}$ and $\bar{b}_{t}^{i} \leq \varepsilon$.
Proof. We choose to present the proof for $\bar{b}_{t}^{i}=0$ to show the proof methodology and avoid making the notation burdensome; similar argument holds for positive $\left|\bar{b}_{t}^{i}\right|$ and $\left(\bar{b}_{t}^{i}\right)^{2}$. The first inequality is a combination of Claim E. 2 and Claim E.3. ${ }^{6}$ Now we tackle the second portion.

First, we write:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[R_{i}\left(\theta_{T}^{\prime}\right)-p_{t}^{i}\left(\vec{m}_{t}^{\prime}\right)-\left(R_{i}\left(\theta_{T}\right)-p_{t}^{i}\left(\vec{m}_{t}\right)\right)\right] \leq & \frac{\sqrt{2 \mathcal{C}_{t}} \gamma_{t} L}{N} \sqrt{\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\bar{a}_{t}^{i}-1\right)^{2}\left\|g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]} \\
& -C_{t} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\bar{a}_{t}^{i}-1\right)^{2}\left\|g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]
\end{aligned}
$$

Next, the right-hand side expression is a downwards-curved quadratic, and has roots

$$
\sqrt{\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\bar{a}_{t}^{i}-1\right)^{2}\left\|g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}^{\prime}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]}=0
$$

and

$$
\sqrt{\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\bar{a}_{t}^{i}-1\right)^{2}\left\|g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]}=\frac{\sqrt{2 \mathcal{C}_{t}} \gamma_{t} L}{N C_{t}}
$$

Then if $C_{t}=\frac{\sqrt{2 \mathcal{C}_{t}} \gamma_{t} L}{N \varepsilon}$, for both roots we have $\sqrt{\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\bar{a}_{t}^{i}-1\right)^{2}\left\|g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]} \leq \varepsilon$. Now observe that the quadratic is positive only between the two roots, i.e. when $0 \leq \sqrt{\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\bar{a}_{t}^{i}-1\right)^{2}\left\|g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]} \leq \varepsilon$. Therefore,

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[R_{i}\left(\theta_{T}^{\prime}\right)-p_{t}^{i}\left(\vec{m}_{t}^{\prime}\right)-\left(R_{i}\left(\theta_{T}\right)-p_{t}^{i}\left(\vec{m}_{t}\right)\right)\right] \leq \frac{\sqrt{2 \mathcal{C}_{t}} \gamma_{t} L}{N} \sqrt{\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\bar{a}_{t}^{i}-1\right)^{2}\left\|g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]}
$$

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{6}$ In particular, we can ignore the first $t-1$ steps because they are identical for both trajectories, so the bound in Claim E. 2 is relevant only for steps $\geq t$.

$$
\begin{aligned}
& -C_{t} \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\bar{a}_{t}^{i}-1\right)^{2}\left\|g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\right] \\
\leq & \frac{\sqrt{2 C_{t}} \gamma_{t} L}{N} \sqrt{\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\bar{a}_{t}^{i}-1\right)^{2}\left\|g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]} \\
\leq & \frac{\sqrt{2 C_{t}} \gamma_{t} L \varepsilon}{N}
\end{aligned}
$$

Claim E. 5 (Total bound on utility difference between trajectories). Suppose $\theta^{\prime}$ denotes some arbitrary reporting strategy and $\theta$ denotes truthful reporting. That is we don't require them to be the same up to the last step. Then:

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[R_{i}\left(\theta_{T+1}^{\prime}\right)-\sum_{t=1}^{T} p_{t}^{i}\left(\vec{m}_{t}^{\prime}\right)-\left(R_{i}\left(\theta_{T+1}\right)-\sum_{t=1}^{T} p_{t}^{i}\left(\vec{m}_{t}\right)\right)\right] \leq \frac{\sqrt{2} L G \varepsilon}{N}
$$

where $G=\sum_{t=1}^{T} \gamma_{t} \sqrt{\mathcal{C}_{t}}$.
Proof. Combine Claim E. 2 with Proposition E. 4 and telescope. In particular, starting from the last time step we turn the trajectory produced by possible misreporting to one produced by truthful reporting by comparing the maximal gain in utility from the action of client $i$ at time $t$.

# F Proof of Theorem 5.2 

We repeat the statement for completeness.
Claim F. 1 (Bound on individual payments). Suppose all participants are approximately truthful at each time step. Then the total payment is bounded by

$$
\sum_{t=1}^{T} p_{t}^{i}\left(\vec{m}_{t}\right) \leq \frac{\sqrt{2} L G}{N}\left[2 \varepsilon^{2}+2 \varepsilon \sigma+2 \zeta^{2}+\rho^{2}\right]+\frac{\sqrt{8} L \varepsilon}{N} \sum_{t=1}^{T} \gamma_{t} \sqrt{\mathcal{C}_{t}}\left\|\nabla F_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|
$$

where $G=\sum_{t=1}^{T} \gamma_{t} \sqrt{\mathcal{C}_{t}}$.
Proof. First, we consider a single time step: ${ }^{9}$

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{p_{t}^{i}\left(\vec{m}_{t}\right)}{C_{t}} & =\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\bar{a}_{t}^{i} g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)+b_{t}^{i} \zeta_{t}^{i}\right\|^{2}-\frac{1}{N-1} \sum_{j \neq i}\left\|\bar{a}_{t}^{j} g_{j}\left(\theta_{t}\right)+b_{t}^{j} \zeta_{t}^{j}\right\|^{2}\right] \\
& \leq \mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\bar{a}_{t}^{i} g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}-\frac{1}{N-1} \sum_{j \neq i}\left\|\bar{a}_{t}^{j} g_{j}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]+\varepsilon^{2} \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\bar{a}_{t}^{i} e_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]+\left\|\bar{a}_{t}^{i} \nabla F_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}-\frac{1}{N-1}\left(\sum_{j \neq i} \mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\bar{a}_{t}^{j} e_{j}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]+\left\|\bar{a}_{t}^{j} \nabla F_{j}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\right)+\varepsilon^{2} \\
& \leq \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\left(\bar{a}_{t}^{i}\right)^{2}-1\right)\left\|g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]+2 \zeta^{2}+\rho^{2}+\varepsilon^{2} \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\bar{a}_{t}^{i}-1\right)^{2}\left\|g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[2\left(\bar{a}_{t}^{i}-1\right)\left\|g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]+2 \zeta^{2}+\rho^{2}+\varepsilon^{2} \\
& \leq 2 \varepsilon^{2}+2 \varepsilon \sqrt{\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]}+2 \zeta^{2}+\rho^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{9}$ We divide by $C_{t}$ to make the exposition more concise.

$$
\leq 2 \varepsilon^{2}+2 \varepsilon\left\|\nabla F_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|+2 \varepsilon \sigma+2 \zeta^{2}+\rho^{2}
$$

The second line uses the fact that $\xi_{t}^{t}$ is mean zero, variance one and independent of everything, alongside the assumption that all clients are approximately truthful. The third line is rearrangement. The forth line applies Assumption 2.3 and 2.4. The fifth line is rearrangement. The sixth applies the approximate truthfulness assumption $\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|a_{t}^{i} g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)-g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\right] \leq \varepsilon^{2}$. Claim I. 1 yields the last inequality.

Therefore, over all time steps we have:

$$
\sum_{t=1}^{T} p_{t}^{i}\left(\vec{m}_{t}\right) \leq \frac{\sqrt{2} L G}{N}\left[2 \varepsilon^{2}+2 \varepsilon \sigma+2 \zeta^{2}+\rho^{2}\right]+\frac{\sqrt{8} L \varepsilon}{N} \sum_{t=1}^{T} \gamma_{t} \sqrt{\mathcal{C}_{t}}\left\|\nabla F_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|
$$

# G Proof of Theorem 5.3 

What follows is the proof of Theorem 5.3, which establishes the convergence rate in the approximately truthful setting. First, we mention a useful result due to Bottou et al. (2018), then we bound the variance of the aggregate gradient at each step (Claim G.3). The full proof is at the end. We also give a slightly different bound using a result due to Chung (1954).

## G. 1 Results from the literature

Lemma G. 1 (Equation 4.23, Theorem 4.7 (Bottou et al., 2018)). Let $F$ be a continuously differentiable function that is $H$-smooth and $m$-strongly-convex. Let $g(\theta)$ be a stochastic gradient of $F$ at $\theta$, such that $\mathbb{E}[g(\theta)]=\nabla F(\theta)$. Suppose there exist scalars $M, M_{V} \geq 0$, such that $\operatorname{Var}\left[g\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right] \leq M+M_{V}\left\|\nabla F_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}$ for every $t$. If we run $S G D$ with $\gamma_{t}=\frac{\gamma}{\eta+1}$, where $\gamma>\frac{1}{m}, \eta>0$ and $\gamma_{1} \leq \frac{1}{H\left(M_{V}+1\right)}$, then ${ }^{10}$

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[F\left(\theta_{t+1}\right)-F\left(\theta^{*}\right)\right] \leq\left(1-\gamma_{t} m\right) \mathbb{E}\left[F\left(\theta_{t}\right)-F\left(\theta^{*}\right)\right]+\frac{\gamma_{t}^{2} H M}{2}
$$

and

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[F\left(\theta_{t}\right)-F\left(\theta^{*}\right)\right] \leq \max \left\{\frac{\gamma^{2} H M}{2(\gamma m-1)(\eta+t)}, \frac{(\eta+1)\left(F\left(\theta_{1}\right)-F\left(\theta^{*}\right)\right)}{\eta+t}\right\}
$$

Lemma G. 2 (Lemma 1 (Chung, 1954)). Suppose that $\left\{b_{n}\right\}_{n \in \mathbb{N}}$ is a sequence of real numbers such that for $n \geq n_{0}$,

$$
b_{n+1} \leq\left(1-\frac{c}{n}\right) b_{n}+\frac{c_{1}}{n^{p+1}}
$$

where $c>p>0, c_{1}>0$. Then

$$
b_{n} \leq \frac{c_{1}}{c-p} \frac{1}{n^{p}}+O\left(\frac{1}{n^{p+1}}+\frac{1}{n^{c}}\right)
$$

## G. 2 The proof

Claim G. 3 (Bound on the variance of the aggregated gradient). Suppose that there exist scalars $M, M_{V} \geq 0$, such that for every $t$ we have:

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|e_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\right] \leq M+M_{V}\left\|\nabla F\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}
$$

If all participants are approximately truthful at each time step $t$, then:

$$
\operatorname{Var}\left[\frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^{n} a_{t}^{i} g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)+b_{t}^{i} \xi_{t}^{i}\right] \leq \frac{2\left(2 \varepsilon^{2}+M+2 M_{V} \zeta^{2}\right)}{N}+\frac{2 M_{V}}{N}\left\|\nabla F\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}
$$

[^0]
[^0]:    ${ }^{10}$ In the original results, there is two additional variables $\mu$ and $\mu_{G}$. Here we can set them to $\mu_{G}=\mu=1$, so we choose to simplify the write-up and ignore them.

where for a stochastic gradient $g$ we use $\operatorname{Var}[g]=\mathbb{E}\left[\|g-\mathbb{E}[g]\|^{2}\right]$ for the variance of the squared $\ell_{2}$ norm of the error of $g$ with respect to its mean $\mathbb{E}[g]$.

Proof. Observe the following series of inequalities. Recall that $\xi_{t}^{i}$ is mean zero and variance one and is independent of everything, so we can quite easily take care of the noise terms.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\operatorname{Var}\left[\frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^{N} a_{t}^{i} g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right] & =\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^{N} a_{t}^{i} g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)+b_{t}^{i} \xi_{t}^{i}\right\|^{2}\right]-\left\|\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{1}{N} \sum_{i=1}^{N} a_{t}^{i} g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)+b_{t}^{i} \xi_{t}^{i}\right]\right\|^{2} \\
& =\frac{1}{N^{2}} \mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\sum_{i=1}^{N} a_{t}^{i} e_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)+\sum_{i=1}^{N} a_{t}^{i} \nabla F_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]+\frac{\varepsilon^{2}}{N}-\frac{1}{N^{2}}\left\|\sum_{i=1}^{N} a_{t}^{i} \nabla F_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2} \\
& =\frac{1}{N^{2}} \sum_{i=1}^{N} \mathbb{E}\left[\left\|a_{t}^{i} e_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]+\frac{1}{N^{2}}\left\|\sum_{i=1}^{N} a_{t}^{i} \nabla F_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}-\frac{1}{N^{2}}\left\|\sum_{i=1}^{N} a_{t}^{i} \nabla F_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}+\frac{\varepsilon^{2}}{N} \\
& \leq \frac{3 \varepsilon^{2}}{N}+\frac{2}{N^{2}} \sum_{i=1}^{N} \mathbb{E}\left[\left\|e_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\right] \\
& \leq \frac{2\left(2 \varepsilon^{2}+M\right)}{N}+\frac{2 M_{V}}{N^{2}} \sum_{i=1}^{N}\left\|\nabla F_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2} \\
& \leq \frac{2\left(2 \varepsilon^{2}+M+M_{V} \zeta^{2}\right)}{N}+\frac{2 M_{V}}{N}\left\|\nabla F\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Proof of Theorem 5.3. Once we have Claim G. 3 under out belt, we invoke Lemma G. 1 with $M=\frac{2\left(2 \varepsilon^{2}+M+M_{V} \zeta^{2}\right)}{N}$, $M_{V}=\frac{2 M_{V}}{N}$, and $\gamma_{t}=\frac{\gamma}{\eta+t}=\frac{4}{m(\eta+t)}$, where $\eta=\frac{4 H\left(2 M_{V}+N\right)}{m N}$. This yields:

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[F\left(\theta_{t}\right)-F\left(\theta^{*}\right)\right] \leq \max \left\{\frac{16 H\left(2 \varepsilon^{2}+M+M_{V} \zeta^{2}\right)}{3 N m^{2}(\eta+t)}, \frac{(\eta+1)\left(F\left(\theta_{1}\right)-F\left(\theta^{*}\right)\right)}{\eta+t}\right\}
$$

Alternative bound for Theorem 5.3. Once we have Claim G. 3 under out belt, we invoke Lemma G. 1 with $M=\frac{2\left(2 \varepsilon^{2}+M+M_{V} \zeta^{2}\right)}{N}, M_{V}=\frac{2 M_{V}}{N}$, and $\gamma_{t}=\frac{\gamma}{\eta+t}=\frac{4}{m(\eta+t)}$, where $\eta=\frac{4 H\left(2 M_{V}+N\right)}{m N}$. This yields:

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[F\left(\theta_{t+1}\right)-F\left(\theta^{*}\right)\right] \leq\left(1-\frac{4}{\eta+t}\right) \mathbb{E}\left[F\left(\theta_{t}\right)-F\left(\theta^{*}\right)\right]+\frac{16 H\left(2 \varepsilon^{2}+M+M_{V} \zeta^{2}\right)}{N m^{2}(\eta+t)^{2}}
$$

Finally, we use Lemma G. 2 with $p=1, c=4$ and $c_{1}=\frac{16 H\left(\varepsilon^{2}+M\right)}{N m^{2}}$, to get:

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[F\left(\theta_{t}\right)-F\left(\theta^{*}\right)\right] \leq \frac{16 H\left(2 \varepsilon^{2}+M+M_{V} \zeta^{2}\right)}{3 N m^{2}(\eta+t)}+O\left(\frac{1}{t^{2}}+\frac{1}{t^{4}}\right)
$$

# H Extending the action space 

The generalizations of our main results follow from the main analysis with very few modifications. The proofs below state what changes need to be made and note any peculiarities that emerge from generalizing the analysis.

Proof of Claim 5.6. In all equations in Appendices E, F and G the scaling factor $a_{t}^{i}$ always appears under the expectation sign. We need to make sure that in all proofs we substitute $\left|\tilde{b}_{t}^{i}\right|$ and $\left(\tilde{b}_{t}^{i}\right)^{2}$ with $\sqrt{\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\tilde{b}_{t}^{i}\right)^{2}\right]}$ and $\mathbb{E}\left[\left(\tilde{b}_{t}^{i}\right)^{2}\right]$. Then the results follow quite directly for mixed strategies that are independent of the stochasticity in the learning protocol.

Proof of Claim 5.7. We can allow $\bar{a}_{t}^{i}$ to depend on the history of the protocol, that is $\bar{a}_{t}^{i}$ can be a random variable bounded below by 1 almost surely that depends on the previous model parameters $\left\{\theta_{j}\right\}_{j=1}^{t}$ and the previous gradients $\left\{g_{i}\left(\theta_{1}\right)\right\}_{j=1}^{t-1}$ sent by client $i$. In particular, the important fact for the proofs above is that $\bar{a}_{t}^{i}$ is independent of the randomness in $g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)$ and that $\bar{a}_{t}^{i} \geq 1$ almost surely. The same goes for the DP noise $\tilde{b}_{t}^{i}$ as long as it's independent of $g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)$ and $\bar{a}_{t}^{i}$. In particular, notice that in the results in Claim E. 3 and Claim E. 2 the expectation on the right-hand side is taken just on the random variable $g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)$ (which depends on the history of the protocol), so these bounds hold in expectation over the gradient that is sampled at time step $t$.

Proof of Claim 5.8. Recall that $\left\|h_{t}^{i}\right\|=a_{i}^{t}\left\|g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|$ and $\left\langle h_{t}^{i}, g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\rangle \geq\left\|g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}$ by the construction in Claim 5.8. Moreover, Cauchy-Schwartz gives $\left\langle h_{t}^{i}, g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\rangle \leq a_{t}^{i}\left\|g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}$, so

$$
\left\|g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2} \leq\left\langle h_{t}^{i}, g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\rangle \leq a_{t}^{i}\left\|g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}
$$

Now throughout our analysis in Appendices $\mathrm{E}, \mathrm{F}$ and G we need to substitute $\bar{a}_{t}^{i} g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)$ with $h_{t}^{i}$. Note that above we used $a_{i}^{t}$ to denote the strategy used under the statement of Claim 5.8, while here $\bar{a}_{t}^{i}$ is the scaling factor used in our analysis in Appendix E. We only need to make sure that in Claim E. 3 the righthand side remains as $C_{t} \mathbb{E}\left[\left\|g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}-\left\|h_{t}^{i}\right\|\right]$, without bounding that quantity with something equivalent to $-C_{t}\left(\bar{a}_{t}^{i}-1\right)^{2} \mathbb{E}\left[\left\|g_{i}\left(\theta_{t}\right)\right\|^{2}\right]$

# I Bound on stochastic gradient norm 

Claim I.1. Let $F$ and $g$ satisfy the same conditions as $F_{i}$ and $g_{i}$ from Section 2.1. Let $\theta^{*} \in \Theta$ be a minimizer of $F$. For any $\theta \in \Theta$ we have

$$
\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|g_{i}(\theta)\right\|\right] \leq \sqrt{\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|g_{i}(\theta)\right\|^{2}\right]} \leq \sqrt{\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|g_{i}(\theta)\right\|^{2}\right]} \leq\left\|\nabla F_{i}(\theta)\right\|+\sigma
$$

Proof. Let $e_{i}(\theta)=g_{i}(\theta)-\nabla F_{i}(\theta)$ be the gradient noise. Observe:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|g_{i}(\theta)\right\|^{2}\right] & =\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\nabla F_{i}(\theta)+e_{i}(\theta)\right\|^{2}\right] \\
& =\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\nabla F_{i}(\theta)\right\|^{2}\right]+2 \mathbb{E}\left[\left(\nabla F_{i}(\theta), e_{i}(\theta)\right)\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|e_{i}(\theta)\right\|^{2}\right] \\
& =\left\|\nabla F_{i}(\theta)\right\|^{2}+\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|e_{i}(\theta)\right\|^{2}\right] \\
& \leq\left\|\nabla F_{i}(\theta)\right\|^{2}+\sigma^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

The third line uses the fact that $\mathbb{E}\left[e_{i}(\theta)\right]=0$ for any fixed $\theta \in \Theta$. Finally, because $\sqrt{\cdot}$ is concave and $\left\|g_{i}(\theta)\right\|^{2}$ is a non-negative random variable, Jensen's inequality finishes the claim.

abstract:
Federated learning (FL) is a distributed collaborative learning method, where
multiple clients learn together by sharing gradient updates instead of raw
data. However, it is well-known that FL is vulnerable to manipulated updates
from clients. In this work we study the impact of data heterogeneity on
clients' incentives to manipulate their updates. First, we present
heterogeneous collaborative learning scenarios where a client can modify their
updates to be better off, and show that these manipulations can lead to
diminishing model performance. To prevent such modifications, we formulate a
game in which clients may misreport their gradient updates in order to "steer"
the server model to their advantage. We develop a payment rule that provably
disincentivizes sending modified updates under the FedSGD protocol. We derive
explicit bounds on the clients' payments and the convergence rate of the global
model, which allows us to study the trade-off between heterogeneity, payments
and convergence. Finally, we provide an experimental evaluation of the
effectiveness of our payment rule in the FedSGD, median-based aggregation
FedSGD and FedAvg protocols on three tasks in computer vision and natural
language processing. In all cases we find that our scheme successfully
disincentivizes modifications.
